thread.title: 'Busiest night in years' for P.E.I. plow drivers, but going still slow as blizzard cleanup continues
thread.title_full: 'Busiest night in years' for P.E.I. plow drivers, but going still slow as blizzard cleanup continues

author: cbc
title: 'Busiest night in years' for P.E.I. plow drivers, but going still slow as blizzard cleanup continues
text:
Environment Canada has ended the blizzard warning on P.E.I., but the cleanup is going to take some time after a blizzard dumped at least 40 centimetres of snow between midday and midnight Monday and poor visibility forced plows off the road overnight.
See a full list of cancellations on Storm Centre Call in your cancellations to 1-877-236-9350 With the predicted winds for Tuesday night it will be late evening or early Wednesday morning before things will be fully clear, the province said.
Schools and civil service offices closed for the day and morning flights were cancelled at Charlottetown Airport â€” afternoon and evening flights are delayed or on time, as of 4 p.m. Confederation Bridge reopened just before 9 a.m. after being closed for hours. Mail delivery was cancelled Island-wide. Although the province pulled plows off roads overnight because of poor visibility, some ended up helping with emergency calls.
Fire strikes Hayden Produce during blizzard Blizzard doesn't stop babies 'This was the busiest night in years' This is what downtown streets looked like first thing Tuesday morning. (Karen Mair/CBC)
Charlottetown plows were getting to work on some side streets around 9 a.m. (Tracy Lightfoot/CBC)
"This was the busiest night in years for our drivers in terms of the need to provide emergency escorts," a spokesman for P.E.I.'s Department of Transportation said. Plows assisted emergency vehicles at a major fire in Vernon River and with the delivery of three babies.
Dispatchers warned large drifts on highways meant plows would have to go slow.
"The storm was slow moving with lots of heavy winds which has created a lot of hard-packed snow drifts that we are trying to get through," the provincial spokesman said.
Flurries and blowing snow over exposed areas with wind from the north 40 km/h gusting to 70 resulted in poor visibility in some areas Tuesday.
Sidewalk plow cleans up deep snow in Charlottetown 0:42
Preliminary reports show up to 40 cm snow, winds of 98 km/h Preliminary reports from Environment Canada reported snowfall of 40 cm at the Charlottetown Airport, 36 cm in Bonshaw, P.E.I., and 20 cm in Borden-Carleton.
"There's no place to put it!" said Terry MacDonald as he shovelled snow in Charlottetown Tuesday afternoon.
Recorded wind speeds were up to 98 km/h, as recorded at the Charlottetown Airport:
East Point: 93. Charlottetown Airport: 98. Summerside: 85. North Cape: 83. St. Peters: 70. Harrington: 82. Stanhope: 65. Environment Canada noted these reports are preliminary, and may be updated.
CBC meteorologist Brennan Allen said the snow is pretty much done in Prince County, but Queens and Kings could see more.
CHART: How much snow has fallen at Charlottetown Airport? Many Islanders spent Valentine's Day shovelling their way out of their homes. (Brian Higgins/CBC)
'There's no place to put it!' said Terry MacDonald (right, in yellow) as he shovelled snow in Charlottetown Tuesday. (Brian Higgins/CBC )

With files from Island Morning
